World War 1 centenary in 2014

To mark the centenary of the start of the Great War, we’ve compiled an extensive reading list to help you explore the lead up to war, what happened, its meaning and how it affected our region. It includes non–fiction, novels and poetry.

You can reserve any of these books for collection from your local library.

The road to war

  • Mark Bostridge: The fateful year: England 1914
  • Christopher Clark: The sleepwalkers: How Europe went to war in 1914
  • David Fromkin: Europe’s last summer: Why the world went to war in 1914
  • Max Hastings: Catastrophe: Europe goes to war 1914
  • Margaret MacMillan: The war that ended peace: How Europe abandoned peace for the First World War
  • Allan Mallinson: 1914: Britain, the army and the coming of the First World War

The war

  • Edith Appleton, editor Ruth Cowen: A nurse at the front:the Great War diaries of Sister Edith Appleton
  • Diane Atkinson: Elsie and Mairi go to war: Two extraordinary women on the Western Front
  • Edmund Blunden: Undertones of war
  • Vera Brittain: Testament of youth: An autobiographical study of the years 1900–1925
  • Phil Carradice: First World War in the air
  • Les Carlyon: Gallipoli
  • Peter Doyle: Great War Tommy: An insight into the uniform, equipment, weaponry and lifestyle of the British Great War soldier
  • Harry Drinkwater, Editors Jon Cooksey & David Griffiths: Harry’s war: The Great War diary of Harry Drinkwater
  • Thomas Fegan: The ‘baby killers’: German air raids on Britain in the First World War
  • Niall Ferguson: The pity of war
  • David Fletcher, David Willey & Matt Sampson: Great War tank: An insight into the history, development, production and role of the main British Army tank of the First World War
  • Robert Graves: Goodbye to all that
  • The Great War: A photographic narrative
  • Neil Hanson: The unknown soldier: The story of the missing of the Great War
  • Richard Holmes: Tommy: The British soldier on the Western Front, 1914-1918
  • Tonie Holt & Valmai Holt: Major & Mrs Holt’s pocket battlefield guide to Ypres & Passchendaele
  • Ernst Junger: Storm of steel
  • John Keegan: The First World War
  • Editors Barbara Korte & Ann-Marie Einhaus: The Penguin book of First World War stories
  • John Lewis-Stempel: Six weeks: the short and gallant life of the British officer in the First World War
  • E.P.F. Lynch, edited by L.Will Davies: Somme mud: The experiences of an infantryman in France, 1916-1919
  • Lyn MacDonald: Passchendaele: The story of the Third Battle of Ypres 1917
  • E.R. Mayhew: Wounded: From battlefield to Blighty, 1914-1918
  • Martin Middlebrook: The first day on the Somme: 1st July, 1916
  • Harry Patch & Richard Van Emden: The last fighting Tommy: The life of Harry Patch, the oldest surviving veteran of the trenches
  • Joe Sacco & Adam Hochschild: The Great War: An illustrated panorama
  • Siegfried Sassoon: Memoirs of an infantry officer
  • G.D. Sheffield: The First World War in 100 objects: The story of the Great War told through the objects that shaped it
  • David Stevenson: 1914-1918: The history of the First World War
  • Norman Stone: World War One: A short history
  • Stanley Weintraub: Silent night: The remarkable Christmas truce of 1914
  • The Wipers Times: The famous First World War trench newspaper

The legacy of the war

  • Kate Adie: Fighting on the Home Front: The legacy of women in World War One
  • Clive Aslet: War memorial: The story of one village’s sacrifice from 1914 to 2003
  • Commonwealth War Graves Commission website
  • David Crane: Empires of the dead: How one man’s vision led to the creation of WWI’s war graves
  • Simon Fowler: Tracing your First World War ancestors
  • Jeremy Paxman: Great Britain’s Great War
  • David Reynolds: The long shadow: The Great War and the twentieth century

Poetry

  • Editor: Carol Ann Duffy: 1914: Poetry remembers
  • Wilfred Owen, edited by Jon Stallworthy: The war poems of Wilfred Owen
  • Editor: George Walter: The Penguin book of First World War poetry

Fiction

  • Pat Barker: The regeneration trilogy
  • John Boyne: The absolutist
  • Sebastian Faulks: Birdsong
  • Ford Madox Ford: Parade’s end
  • Ernest Hemingway: A farewell to arms
  • Erich Maria Remarque, translator Brian Murdoch: All quiet on the Western Front

Suffolk’s war

  • Gerald Gliddon: Norfolk and Suffolk in the Great War
  • CCR Murphy: The History of the Suffolk Regiment 1914-1927
  • Valerie Herbert: No glorious dead: The impact of war on Sudbury, a Suffolk market town
  • Robert B. Jarvis: Bombardment of Lowestoft & Great Yarmouth by the Germans, 25th April 1916
  • Mark Mower: Zeppelin over Suffolk
